list_definition.definition: to (cause to) give out light; to direct such light towards someone or something

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The light shone from the window
He shone a torch on the body.
She polished the silver till it shone.

list_definition.definition: (past tense, past participle shined) to polish

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He tries to make a living by shining shoes.

list_definition.definition: (often with at) to be very good (at something)

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: You really shone in yesterday’s match.

list_definition.definition: brightness; the state of being well polished

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He likes a good shine on his shoes
I’ll just give my shoes a shine.

list_ex_of_english: With the sun shining and with time off, that is lovely.
The quality of academic knowledge shines through from the wide array of academic contributors.
She was a shining example of a person who lived by the possibly outmoded work ethic.
She has arrived like a knight in shining armour at the eleventh hour, and she should be congratulated for that.
The first two derive from the sun, which shines on every roof in every town.
Good teachers with small classes in our schools are better than bad teachers with large classes in nice, new, shining schools.
If we were to emulate that shining example of fairness, that £500 million in 1976 would today require us to deny those people £925 million—nearly £1 billion.
The sun shines, and the sky is blue.
